Thanks Jim for your encouraging reply ! And ofcourse for taking the time
to explain the Akasaka situation in a little more detail. Much much
appreciated ! 
 
Now back to the books for me ...................... I still have an
awful lot to learn, but I enjoy it and that is important. 
 
- Matt 

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...] 
Verzonden: zondag 29 juni 2003 7:20
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Early sukashi tsuba attribution


Matt,
Very good calls -- well done.  However, I have to say that Akasaka would
be difficult to defend.  That mokko shape would be very unusual for
Akasaka.  Their seppa dai tended to be more narrow and were often
somewhat to very pointed at the top in the early generations.  The broad
shape would be, again unusual.  They didn't normally do quadrilateral
symmetry like that and the hitsuana are also not typical, although
Tadashige often made "dovetails" for (often non-existent) sekigane like
we see here on the kozuka ana side.  Akasaka construction often used a
hard, smooth kawagane that looks quite different from the texture of the
iron on this guard.  The rim is usually very round in the early
generations.

BUT... there are a bunch of signed Akasaka guards by later generations
that are not obviously in Akasaka style based on the carving, motifs and
even inlay.  It's an interesting study.   The first Akasaka died around
1657, FWIW.  Pretty sure it's not an Akasaka piece, though.

Writing opinions is a great way to learn.  Keep it up and don't worry
about the feet.  You did good.

Jim


  This is my totally uninformed novice opinion. So feel free to put your
  foot in if I am way off base here.  Anyway with that disclaimer gone
  here goes (I have to try sometime haha)

  My first guess would be Kyoto for the first tsuba, second guess
Akasaka,
  whatever it is dating to the (early) 1600's

  Second tsuba: I am inclined to agree with Tom, early simple Onin. 

  How did I do ? 

  - Matt
